Bibliography

Here is a curated list of resources to get you going on using Static Site Generators and the JAMstack model of site development.

Learn

Intro articles

  • An introduction to the JAMstack: the architecture of the modern web
  • Questions to ask before choosing a static site generator
  • Beginner’s Guide to Static Site Generators: A design house blog post offers a geekier introduction to the latest top crop of SSGs.
  • Comparing SSG build times
  • Going Headless: Use Cases And What It’s Good For

Resources and Tutorials

  • Jamstack Conference: Free videos repository from their conferences.
  • Jamstack Learning Resources
  • Building a static website with Jekyll and GitHub Pages: From The Programming Historian.
  • Using Static Site Generators for Scholarly Publications and Open Educational Resources: from the Code4Lib Journal
  • Creating and Hosting a Personal Site on GitHub
  • Get Started with Markdown: Markdown is a popular content markup syntax that is quicker and more convenient to use than hard coding HTML for your pages.
  • Liquid Basics: Liquid is the templating language used in Jekyll and others SSGs.
  • 15 minute hands-on web tutorial on using Git: Git is the version-control code repository for SSGs.

Tools

Resource listing

These sites consolidate all the resources and offer multiple methods of narrowing the massive list, such as the base language the apps were created with. They both include learning resources such as training videos.

  • Jamstack.org: This site’s tools directory focuses on SSGs and CMS products and also includes videos and learning materials. Sponsored by Netlify.
  • The New Dynamic: This directory looks at the wider ecosystem and includes critical SSG integrations such as e-commerce and comment handling tools.

Popular SSGs

  • Jekyll: Written in Ruby, this is the godfather of the Jamstack movement.
  • Hugo: Built for speed, this system is also widely used in academia. Written in Go.
  • Gatsby: React-based SSG written to support wide-range of site types.
  • 11ty: Eleventy was created as a simpler Javascript-based alternative to Jekyll. Supports 11 templating languages.
  • Next.js: This is an option if you’re looking to span the gap between web applications and static site generation.

Popular Graphical Front Ends

There are dozens of SSG front ends. Here are select ones that are open source or have free options for one-off sites…

  • Jekyll Admin: Gem provides editing interface for a specific project
  • SiteLeaf: Individual accounts are free.
  • NetlifyCMS is an open source tool developed to compliment their CDN hosting.
  • Forestry.io: Individual accounts are free.

Free SSG hosting

  • Github Pages
  • Surge.sh
  • Netlify

Example projects

SSGs in academia

  • Programs in Digital Humanities: This MIT site was created by Eleventy.
  • How we made the Mid-Michigan website faster: Mid-Michigan College redesigned in 2019 using Gatsby.
  • Digital Collections from the Columbia University Libraries: The Biggert Collection of Architectural Vignettes and The Barbara Curtis Adachi Bunraku Collection
  • Historical Topographic Map Digitizaton Project from the Ontario Council of University Libraries was created with Hugo.
  • Archives Unleashed Project is built with Hugo.
  • Getty Museum digital publications: The Getty created the Quire project as an extension of Hugo for creating multi-format digital publications.
  • Research labs using Jekyll: Riggleman Computational Soft Matter Lab at the University of Pennsylvania and the Zhou Lab, a structural biology lab at the University of Chicago.
  • Universities promoting use of SSGs: UC Berkeley, SUNY Buffalo, Rutgers, and Jekyll Academic theme from North Carolina State.

Additional SSG-built sites

  • Virginia.gov using Hugo
  • Vote.gov using Hugo
  • Visit Paris is the region’s official visitors guide. Created using Hugo.
  • United Nations World Statistics Day
  • Code4Lib National Conference was created using Jekyll.
  • Smashing Magazine is a popular online web dev magazine that uses Hugo. Here is the story of their switch to an SSG; and an early article about lessons learned.
  • Hybrid web app, static sites created with Next.js include AT&T and Hulu
